content.value: What is Basic Text Editing in Linux?
Text editing in Linux means opening and modifying text files directly inside the terminal using built-in editors.
We use text editors like nano, vi, and vim to edit files such as notes, configuration files, scripts, or system settings without needing a graphical app.

items: vi : the traditional Unix editor, available on almost every system
vim : an improved, modern version of vi with more features

content.value: Start with nano → learn the basics. Move to vi → learn system editing. Upgrade to vim → for advanced editing.
nano is the easiest editor: the shortcuts are displayed at the bottom and you can start typing immediately.

steps: Type normally to write text in the file.
Save changes: CTRL + O, then press ENTER

value: Cut the selected line or text

content.description: Opens the file in nano. If the file doesn't exist, nano will create it.

content.value: If you're unsure which editor to start with, nano is the safest and simplest option.
Editing with vi & vim (For Intermediate to Advanced Users)
vi and vim are modal editors, meaning you switch between typing text and running commands. They are fast and powerful once you learn the basics.

vi is the original editor and is installed by default on almost every Unix/Linux system. vim (Vi IMproved) is a newer, feature-rich version with syntax highlighting, plugins, undo history, and better navigation.

value: For basic editing on older or minimal Linux systems (like servers or rescue mode).
For daily development work, coding, configuration editing, and advanced text operations.

content.value: Quick memory trick: If the system has vim, use vim. If not, vi will always be available.
